text: Pleomele hawaiiensis, the Hawaii hala pepe, is a rare species of flowering plant that is endemic to the island of Hawaii in the state of Hawaii. It inhabits dry forests on old aā lava flows at elevations of on the leeward side of the island. Associated plants include: ōhia lehua (Metrosideros polymorpha), lama (Diospyros sandwicensis), māmane (Sophora chrysophylla), alahee (Psydrax odorata), huehue (Cocculus orbiculatus), naio (Myoporum sandwicense), olopua (Nestegis sandwicensis), kuluī (Nototrichium sandwicense), ilima (Sida fallax), wiliwili (Erythrina sandwicensis), iliahi (Santalum spp.), ūlei (Osteomeles anthyllidifolia), uhiuhi (Caesalpinia kavaiensis), kauila (Colubrina oppositifolia), maola (Neraudia ovata), maiapilo (Capparis sandwichiana), Bidens micrantha ssp. ctenophylla, and aiea (Nothocestrum breviflorum). There are 300 to 400 individuals remaining. It is an endangered species, threatened with habitat loss and modification. The flowers of this plant were used in leis and the wood in carvings. ==References== Category:Nolinoideae Category:Endemic flora of Hawaii Category:Biota of Hawaii (island) Category:Trees of Hawaii Category:Plants described in 1980 Category:Taxonomy articles created by Polbot
title: Pleomele hawaiiensis
